sections.procedure:
1.  The case originated in three applications against Ukraine lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by three Ukrainian nationals: Mr Mikhail Igorevich Belyayev (“the first applicant” application no. 34345/10, lodged on 3 March 2010), Mr Ivan Ivanovych Karpenko (“the second applicant” – application no. 50687/10, lodged on 16 August 2010) and Mr Rustam Zakirovich Farziyev (“the third applicant” – application no. 70492/13, lodged on 28 October 2013).
2.  The first applicant was represented by Mr T. Kalmykov, a lawyer practising in Kharkiv. The second applicant, who was granted legal aid, was represented by Ms H. Ovdiienko, a lawyer practising in Kharkiv, and the third applicant, who was also granted legal aid, was represented by Ms N. Okhotnikova, a lawyer practising in Kyiv. The Ukrainian Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent, Mr I. Lishchyna.
3.  The applicants complained under Article 14 of the Convention, read in conjunction with Article 8 of the Convention, of discrimination due to differing visiting rights which had been laid down by the domestic legislation in respect of male and female life prisoners.
4.  On 16 May 2018 notice of the above complaints was given to the Government and the remainder of the applications was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
5.  The Government objected to the examination of the applications by a Committee, but provided no reasons. After having considered the Government’s objection, the Court rejects it.
sections.circumstances:
6.  The first, second and third applicants were born in 1981, 1973 and 1984 respectively. Since 2004 they have been serving life sentences in correctional colonies in Ukraine.
7.  On 11 July 2003 the Ukrainian Parliament adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences of Ukraine (“the Code”). Article 150 of the Code (“Place of serving life imprisonment”) provided that life prisoners were to serve their sentences in maximum-security correctional colonies. Article 151 (“Procedure for, and conditions of, the execution and serving of life sentences”) further provided, inter alia , that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every six months. No reference to prisoners’ gender was made in those Articles. At the same time, Article 18 (“Correctional colonies”) provided that female life prisoners were to serve their sentences in medium-security colonies. In turn, Article 139 (“Medium-security correctional colonies”) provided that prisoners serving their sentences in such colonies were entitled, inter alia , to have one short visit every month and one long visit every three months. Article 110 specified that a short visit from relatives or other persons could last for up to four hours and a long visit from close relatives could last for up to three days.
8.  By a letter of 27 June 2007 the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences informed the second applicant, in reply to a letter sent by him on an earlier date, that female life prisoners were entitled to have one long visit every three months, as provided by Article 139 of the Code, given that they served their sentences in medium-security colonies, as provided by Article 18 of the Code. Referring, in particular, to Article 151 of the Code, the Department further stated that male life prisoners were entitled to have one short visit every six months and that they were not entitled to have long visits.
9.  On 21 January 2010 the Code was amended (“the 2010 amendments”). Article 150, as amended, stated that persons sentenced to life imprisonment were to serve their sentences as follows: male prisoners  either in maximum-security sectors of medium-security correctional colonies or in maximum-security correctional colonies; and female prisoners – either in medium-security sectors of minimum-security correctional colonies with general conditions of detention or in medium-security correctional colonies. Article 151, as amended, stated that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every three months. A newly introduced Article 151² (“Specifics regarding the serving of sentences by female life prisoners”) provided that female life prisoners were to be placed, as a rule, in medium-security sectors of minimum-security colonies with general conditions of detention. It also provided that female life prisoners were to be subject to the regime laid down for prisoners held in mediumsecurity colonies (that is, the regime provided for in Article 139 of the Code).
10.  By the Law of 8 April 2014 on the introduction of amendments to the Code relating to the adaptation of status of convicted persons to European standards the Code was amended again (“the 2014 amendments”). Article 151 was amended to entitle all life prisoners to one short visit every month and one long visit every three months regardless of the type of correctional colony in which they were detained or the security regime to which they were subject.
11.  Further amendments to Article 151 of the Code, which were passed by Parliament on 7 September 2016, entitled all life prisoners to one long visit every two months.
12.  The first applicant stated that he and his family had wished to maintain their relationships, but as the result of the absence of the right to long visits until 2014 he had had to divorce his wife. His father, grandfather and grandmother had died in 2008, 2009 and 2014 respectively and he had not been able to see them while serving his sentence. The Government submitted that while serving his sentence the first applicant had received twenty-eight short visits on unspecified dates and fifteen long visits (between 17 March 2015 and 6 July 2018) from his new wife, mother and his other grandmother.
13.  The second applicant stated that, because of the lack of the opportunity to have long visits until 2014, he had lost contact with his family. His relatives had died – in particular he referred to his father having died in 2012 – and when the 2014 amendments entitled him to long visits, there had no longer been anyone to visit him. The Government submitted that while serving his sentence the second applicant had had one short visit in 2005 (from his sister) and had not requested any long visits.
14.  The third applicant stated that, in the absence of the right to long visits until 2014, his right to found a family had been more declaratory than effective as, in particular, he had not been able to have any physical contact in order to conceive children. The Government submitted that while serving his sentence the third applicant had had twelve short visits (between 25 July 2012 and 26 December 2017) and fourteen long visits (between 5 August 2014 and 6 February 2018) from his wife, mother, father and friends.

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY, 1. Decides to join the applications; 2. Declares the applications admissible; 3. Holds that there has been a violation of Article 14 of the Convention, read in conjunction with Article 8 of the Convention; 4. Holds (a) that the respondent State is to pay, within three months, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement: (i) EUR 3,000 (three thousand euros) to the first applicant and EUR 1,500 (one thousand five hundred euros) each to the second and third applicants, plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of nonpecuniary damage; (ii) EUR 850 (eight hundred and fifty euros) to the first applicant, plus any tax that may be chargeable to him, in respect of his costs and expenses, to be paid directly to the account of Mr T. Kalmykov; 5. Dismisses the remainder of the applicants’ claims for just satisfaction.
events.event: made a decision

events.source_text: The first, second and third applicants were born in 1981, 1973 and 1984 respectively. Since 2004 they have been serving life sentences in correctional colonies in Ukraine.

events.source_text: On 11 July 2003 the Ukrainian Parliament adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences of Ukraine (“the Code”). Article 150 of the Code provided that life prisoners were to serve their sentences in maximum-security correctional colonies. Article 151 further provided, inter alia , that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every six months.
events.event: On 11 July 2003, the Ukrainian Parliament adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences of Ukraine.
events.event_what: adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences of Ukraine

events.source_text: Article 18 provided that female life prisoners were to serve their sentences in medium-security correctional colonies. Article 139 provided that prisoners serving their sentences in such colonies were entitled, inter alia , to have one short visit every month and one long visit every three months.
events.event: Articles 18 and 139 of the Code specified conditions for female life prisoners.
events.event_what: female life prisoners were to serve their sentences in medium-security correctional colonies, and they were entitled to one short visit every month and one long visit every three months

events.source_text: By a letter of 27 June 2007 the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences informed the second applicant that female life prisoners were entitled to have one long visit every three months, as provided by Article 139 of the Code.
events.event: On 27 June 2007, the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences informed the second applicant about visiting rights.
events.event_who: the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences
events.event_what: informed the second applicant that female life prisoners were entitled to one long visit every three months under Article 139.

events.source_text: Referring, in particular, to Article 151 of the Code, the Department further stated that male life prisoners were entitled to have one short visit every six months and that they were not entitled to have long visits.
events.event: The State Department for Execution of Sentences referred to Article 151 stating visiting rights for male life prisoners.
events.event_what: male life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every six months and not long visits

events.source_text: On 21 January 2010 the Code was amended. Article 150, as amended, stated that persons sentenced to life imprisonment were to serve their sentences as follows: male prisoners either in maximum-security sectors of medium-security correctional colonies or in maximum-security correctional colonies; and female prisoners – either in medium-security sectors of minimum-security correctional colonies with general conditions of detention or in medium-security correctional colonies.
events.event: On 21 January 2010, the Code was amended regarding serving life imprisonment.
events.event_what: persons sentenced to life imprisonment were to serve their sentences as follows: male prisoners either in maximum-security sectors of medium-security correctional colonies or in maximum-security correctional colonies; and female prisoners – either in medium-security sectors of minimum-security correctional colonies with general conditions of detention or in medium-security correctional colonies.

events.source_text: Article 151, as amended, stated that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every three months. A newly introduced Article 151² provided that female life prisoners were to be placed, as a rule, in medium-security sectors of minimum-security colonies with general conditions of detention.
events.event: The Code was amended on 21 January 2010 regarding Article 151 and the new Article 151².
events.event_what: life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every three months, and female life prisoners were to be placed in medium-security sectors of minimum-security colonies with general conditions of detention

events.source_text: It also provided that female life prisoners were to be subject to the regime laid down for prisoners held in medium-security colonies (that is, the regime provided for in Article 139 of the Code).
events.event: The new Article 151² stated that female life prisoners were to be subject to the regime for medium-security colonies.
events.event_what: female life prisoners were to be subject to the regime laid down for prisoners held in medium-security colonies

events.source_text: By the Law of 8 April 2014 on the introduction of amendments to the Code relating to the adaptation of status of convicted persons to European standards the Code was amended again.
events.event: On 8 April 2014, a new law introduced amendments to the Code for adapting status of convicted persons to European standards.
events.event_what: the Code was amended again with respect to adaptation of status of convicted persons to European standards

events.source_text: Article 151 was amended to entitle all life prisoners to one short visit every month and one long visit every three months regardless of the type of correctional colony in which they were detained or the security regime to which they were subject.
events.event: On 8 April 2014, Article 151 was amended to entitle all life prisoners to visits.
events.event_what: Article 151 was amended to entitle all life prisoners to one short visit every month and one long visit every three months regardless of the type of correctional colony or security regime.

events.source_text: Further amendments to Article 151 of the Code, which were passed by Parliament on 7 September 2016, entitled all life prisoners to one long visit every two months.
events.event: On 7 September 2016, Article 151 was amended again in the Code.
events.event_what: all life prisoners were entitled to one long visit every two months under the amendment of Article 151.

events.source_text: The first applicant stated that, as the result of the absence of the right to long visits until 2014 he had had to divorce his wife. His father, grandfather and grandmother had died in 2008, 2009 and 2014 respectively and he had not been able to see them while serving his sentence.
events.event: The first applicant stated that due to the absence of long visits until 2014 he divorced his wife. His family members died in 2008, 2009 and 2014 respectively during which time he could not visit them.
events.event_what: stated that the absence of long visits until 2014 caused him to divorce his wife, and that family members died in 2008, 2009 and 2014 during which he could not visit them.

events.source_text: The Government submitted that while serving his sentence the first applicant had received twenty-eight short visits on unspecified dates and fifteen long visits (between 17 March 2015 and 6 July 2018) from his new wife, mother and his other grandmother.
events.event: The Government submitted information about visits to the first applicant during his sentence.
events.event_what: submitted that while serving his sentence the first applicant had received twenty-eight short visits on unspecified dates and fifteen long visits from 17 March 2015 to 6 July 2018.

events.source_text: The second applicant stated that, because of the lack of the opportunity to have long visits until 2014, he had lost contact with his family. His relatives had died – in particular he referred to his father having died in 2012 – and when the 2014 amendments entitled him to long visits, there had no longer been anyone to visit him.
events.event: The second applicant stated that due to lack of long visits until 2014, he lost contact with family. His relatives died including his father in 2012, and after the 2014 amendments when entitled to long visits, no one was left to visit him.
events.event_what: stated that lack of opportunity for long visits until 2014 caused loss of contact with family. Relatives died in particular father in 2012, and after the 2014 amendments no one was left to visit him.

events.source_text: The Government submitted that while serving his sentence the second applicant had had one short visit in 2005 (from his sister) and had not requested any long visits.
events.event: The Government submitted information about visits to the second applicant during his sentence.
events.event_what: submitted that while serving his sentence the second applicant had one short visit in 2005 and did not request any long visits.

events.source_text: The third applicant stated that, in the absence of the right to long visits until 2014, his right to found a family had been more declaratory than effective as, in particular, he had not been able to have any physical contact in order to conceive children.
events.event: The third applicant stated that due to absence of long visits until 2014, his right to found a family was ineffective because no physical contact for conception.
events.event_what: stated that in the absence of the right to long visits until 2014, his right to found a family had been more declaratory than effective due to lack of physical contact for conception.

events.source_text: The Government submitted that while serving his sentence the third applicant had twelve short visits (between 25 July 2012 and 26 December 2017) and fourteen long visits (between 5 August 2014 and 6 February 2018) from his wife, mother, father and friends.
events.event: The Government submitted information about visits to the third applicant during his sentence.
events.event_what: submitted that while serving his sentence the third applicant had twelve short visits between 25 July 2012 and 26 December 2017, and fourteen long visits between 5 August 2014 and 6 February 2018.

events.source_text: The Court decided to join the applications; declared the applications admissible; held that there has been a violation of Article 14 read in conjunction with Article 8; held that from the expiry of three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the amounts at rate equal to marginal lending rate plus three percentage points.
events.event: The Court decided to join the applications, declared them admissible, and held a violation of Articles 14 and 8. It also ordered payment with interest.
events.event_what: decided to join the applications; declared the applications admissible; held that there has been a violation of Article 14 read in conjunction with Article 8; and held that simple interest shall be payable on the amounts.

events.source_text: Furthermore, it dismissed the remainder of the applicants’ claims for just satisfaction.
events.event: The Court further dismissed the remainder of the applicants' claims for just satisfaction.

events.event: Three applications were lodged against Ukraine under Article 34 of the Convention by three Ukrainian nationals.

events.source_text: On 11 July 2003 the Ukrainian Parliament adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences of Ukraine ("the Code"). Article 150 of the Code ("Place of serving life imprisonment") provided that life prisoners were to serve their sentences in maximum-security correctional colonies.
events.event: The Ukrainian Parliament adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences of Ukraine, which stated that life prisoners were to serve their sentences in maximum-security correctional colonies.

events.source_text: Article 151 ("Procedure for, and conditions of, the execution and serving of life sentences") further provided, inter alia , that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every six months.
events.event: Life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every six months according to Article 151 of the Code.

events.source_text: At the same time, Article 18 ("Correctional colonies") provided that female life prisoners were to serve their sentences in medium-security colonies.
events.event: Female life prisoners were to serve their sentences in medium-security colonies according to Article 18 of the Code.

events.source_text: In turn, Article 139 ("Medium-security correctional colonies") provided that prisoners serving their sentences in such colonies were entitled, inter alia , to have one short visit every month and one long visit every three months.
events.event: Prisoners serving their sentences in medium-security colonies were entitled to have one short visit every month and one long visit every three months according to Article 139 of the Code.

events.source_text: Article 110 specified that a short visit from relatives or other persons could last for up to four hours and a long visit from close relatives could last for up to three days.
events.event: A short visit from relatives or other persons could last for up to four hours, and a long visit from close relatives could last for up to three days according to Article 110 of the Code.

events.source_text: By a letter of 27 June 2007 the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences informed the second applicant, in reply to a letter sent by him on an earlier date, that female life prisoners were entitled to have one long visit every three months, as provided by Article 139 of the Code, given that they served their sentences in medium-security colonies, as provided by Article 18 of the Code.
events.event: The State Department informed the second applicant that female life prisoners were entitled to have one long visit every three months according to Articles 139 and 18 of the Code.

events.source_text: Referring, in particular, to Article 151 of the Code, the Department further stated that male life prisoners were entitled to have one short visit every six months and that they were not entitled to have long visits.
events.event: The Department further stated that male life prisoners were entitled to have one short visit every six months and were not entitled to have long visits according to Article 151 of the Code.

events.source_text: On 21 January 2010 the Code was amended ("the 2010 amendments"). Article 150, as amended, stated that persons sentenced to life imprisonment were to serve their sentences as follows: male prisoners either in maximum-security sectors of medium-security correctional colonies or in maximum-security correctional colonies; and female prisoners – either in medium-security sectors of minimum-security correctional colonies with general conditions of detention or in medium-security correctional colonies.
events.event: The Code was amended on 21 January 2010, stating that persons sentenced to life imprisonment were to serve their sentences as follows: male prisoners either in maximum-security sectors of medium-security correctional colonies or in maximum-security correctional colonies; and female prisoners – either in medium-security sectors of minimum-security correctional colonies with general conditions of detention or in medium-security correctional colonies.

events.source_text: Article 151, as amended, stated that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every three months.
events.event: Life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every three months according to the amended Article 151 of the Code.

events.source_text: A newly introduced Article 151² ("Specifics regarding the serving of sentences by female life prisoners") provided that female life prisoners were to be placed, as a rule, in medium-security sectors of minimum-security colonies with general conditions of detention.
events.event: A newly introduced Article 151² provided that female life prisoners were to be placed, as a rule, in medium-security sectors of minimum-security correctional colonies with general conditions of detention.

events.source_text: It also provided that female life prisoners were to be subject to the regime laid down for prisoners held in medium-security colonies (that is, the regime provided for in Article 139 of the Code).
events.event: Female life prisoners were to be subject to the regime laid down for prisoners held in medium-security correctional colonies according to the amended Article 151² of the Code.

events.source_text: By the Law of 8 April 2014 on the introduction of amendments to the Code relating to the adaptation of status of convicted persons to European standards the Code was amended again ("the 2014 amendments"). Article 151 was amended to entitle all life prisoners to one short visit every month and one long visit every three months regardless of the type of correctional colony in which they were detained or the security regime to which they were subject.
events.event: The Code was amended again on 8 April 2014, entitling all life prisoners to one short visit every month and one long visit every three months regardless of the type of correctional colony or security regime.

events.source_text: Further amendments to Article 151 of the Code, which were passed by Parliament on 7 September 2016, entitled all life prisoners to one long visit every two months.
events.event: Further amendments to Article 151 of the Code, passed on 7 September 2016, entitled all life prisoners to one long visit every two months.

events.source_text: The first applicant stated that he and his family had wished to maintain their relationships, but as the result of the absence of the right to long visits until 2014 he had had to divorce his wife. His father, grandfather and grandmother had died in 2008, 2009 and 2014 respectively and he had not been able to see them while serving his sentence.
events.event: The first applicant stated that he had to divorce his wife due to the absence of the right to long visits until 2014, and he was unable to see his father, grandfather, and grandmother who died between 2008 and 2014 while serving his sentence.

events.source_text: The second applicant stated that, because of the lack of the opportunity to have long visits until 2014, he had lost contact with his family. His relatives had died – in particular he referred to his father having died in 2012 – and when the 2014 amendments entitled him to long visits, there had no longer been anyone to visit him.
events.event: The second applicant stated that he lost contact with his family due to the lack of opportunity for long visits until 2014, and when the 2014 amendments entitled him to long visits, there was no one left to visit him as his relatives had died.

events.source_text: The third applicant stated that, in the absence of the right to long visits until 2014, his right to found a family had been more declaratory than effective as, in particular, he had not been able to have any physical contact in order to conceive children.
events.event: The third applicant stated that his right to found a family was affected due to the absence of the right to long visits until 2014, and he was unable to have any physical contact to conceive children.

events.event: The Court holds that there was a violation of Articles 14 and 8 of the Convention.

events.source_text: Holds
events.event: Holds

events.source_text: (a)  that the respondent State is to pay, within three months, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement:
events.event: The Court holds that the respondent state is to pay the following amounts within three months.

events.source_text: (i)  EUR 3,000 (three thousand euros) to the first applicant and EUR 1,500 (one thousand five hundred euros) each to the second and third applicants, plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of nonpecuniary damage;
events.event: The Court holds that the respondent state is to pay EUR 3,000 to the first applicant, EUR 1,500 each to the second and third applicants for non-pecuniary damages, plus any applicable taxes.

events.source_text: (ii)  EUR 850 (eight hundred and fifty euros) to the first applicant, plus any tax that may be chargeable to him, in respect of his costs and expenses, to be paid directly to the account of Mr T. Kalmykov;
events.event: The Court holds that the respondent state is to pay EUR 850 to the first applicant for costs and expenses, to be paid directly to the account of Mr T. Kalmykov, plus any applicable taxes.

events.source_text: (b)  that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amounts at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points;
events.event: The Court holds that simple interest shall be payable on the above amounts from the expiry of the mentioned three months until settlement, at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points.

events.source_text: The case originated in three applications against Ukraine lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by three Ukrainian nationals: Mr Mikhail Igorevich Belyayev (“the first applicant” application no. 34345/10, lodged on 3 March 2010), Mr Ivan Ivanovych Karpenko (“the second applicant” – application no. 50687/10, lodged on 16 August 2010) and Mr Rustam Zakirovich Farziyev (“the third applicant” – application no. 70492/13, lodged on 28 October 2013).

events.source_text: The first, second and third applicants were born in 1981, 1973 and 1984 respectively. Since 2004 they have been serving life sentences in correctional colonies in Ukraine.
events.event: Applicants' personal details and sentence information.
events.event_what: born in 1981, 1973, and 1984 respectively; serving life sentences since 2004

events.source_text: On 11 July 2003 the Ukrainian Parliament adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences of Ukraine ("the Code"). Article 150 of the Code ("Place of serving life imprisonment") provided that life prisoners were to serve their sentences in maximum-security correctional colonies. Article 151 ("Procedure for, and conditions of, the execution and serving of life sentences") further provided, inter alia, that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every six months.
events.event: Ukrainian Parliament adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences.
events.event_what: adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences

events.source_text: By a letter of 27 June 2007 the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences informed the second applicant, in reply to a letter sent by him on an earlier date, that female life prisoners were entitled to have one long visit every three months, as provided by Article 139 of the Code, given that they served their sentences in medium-security colonies, as provided by Article 18 of the Code.
events.event: State Department informed second applicant about visiting rights for female life prisoners.
events.event_who: State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences
events.event_what: informed the second applicant about visiting rights for female life prisoners

events.source_text: On 21 January 2010 the Code was amended ("the 2010 amendments"). Article 150, as amended, stated that persons sentenced to life imprisonment were to serve their sentences as follows: male prisoners either in maximum-security sectors of medium-security correctional colonies or in maximum-security correctional colonies; and female prisoners – either in medium-security sectors of minimum-security correctional colonies with general conditions of detention or in medium-security correctional colonies.
events.event: Code was amended regarding life sentence serving places.

events.source_text: By the Law of 8 April 2014 on the introduction of amendments to the Code relating to the adaptation of status of convicted persons to European standards the Code was amended again ("the 2014 amendments"). Article 151 was amended to entitle all life prisoners to one short visit every month and one long visit every three months regardless of the type of correctional colony in which they were detained or the security regime to which they were subject.
events.event: Code was amended again regarding visiting rights for life prisoners.

events.source_text: Further amendments to Article 151 of the Code, which were passed by Parliament on 7 September 2016, entitled all life prisoners to one long visit every two months.
events.event: Parliament passed further amendments to Article 151 of the Code.
events.event_what: passed further amendments to Article 151 of the Code

events.source_text: The first applicant stated that he and his family had wished to maintain their relationships, but as the result of the absence of the right to long visits until 2014 he had had to divorce his wife. His father, grandfather and grandmother had died in 2008, 2009 and 2014 respectively and he had not been able to see them while serving his sentence.
events.event: First applicant's statement about family relationships and absence of right to long visits.
events.event_what: stated that he and his family had wished to maintain their relationships, but as the result of the absence of the right to long visits until 2014 he had had to divorce his wife

events.source_text: The second applicant stated that, because of the lack of the opportunity to have long visits until 2014, he had lost contact with his family. His relatives had died – in particular he referred to his father having died in 2012 – and when the 2014 amendments entitled him to long visits, there had no longer been anyone to visit him.
events.event: Second applicant's statement about losing contact with family due to lack of long visits.
events.event_what: stated that he had lost contact with his family because of the lack of opportunity for long visits until 2014

events.source_text: The third applicant stated that, in the absence of the right to long visits until 2014, his right to found a family had been more declaratory than effective as, in particular, he had not been able to have any physical contact in order to conceive children.
events.event: Third applicant's statement about the impact on his right to found a family due to lack of long visits.
events.event_what: stated that, in the absence of the right to long visits until 2014, his right to found a family had been more declaratory than effective

events.source_text: On 11 July 2003 the Ukrainian Parliament adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences of Ukraine (“the Code”). Article 150 of the Code (“Place of serving life imprisonment”) provided that life prisoners were to serve their sentences in maximum-security correctional colonies. Article 151 (“Procedure for, and conditions of, the execution and serving of life sentences”) further provided, inter alia , that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every six months. No reference to prisoners’ gender was made in those Articles.
events.event: On 11 July 2003, the Ukrainian Parliament adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences of Ukraine (“the Code”). Article 150 of the Code (“Place of serving life imprisonment”) provided that life prisoners were to serve their sentences in maximum-security correctional colonies. Article 151 (“Procedure for, and conditions of, the execution and serving of life sentences”) further provided, inter alia , that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every six months.
events.event_what: the Ukrainian Parliament adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences of Ukraine. Article 150 provided that life prisoners were to serve their sentences in maximum-security correctional colonies. Article 151 further provided that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every six months.

events.source_text: By a letter of 27 June 2007 the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences informed the second applicant, in reply to a letter sent by him on an earlier date, that female life prisoners were entitled to have one long visit every three months, as provided by Article 139 of the Code, given that they served their sentences in medium-security colonies, as provided by Article 18 of the Code. Referring, in particular, to Article 151 of the Code, the Department further stated that male life prisoners were entitled to have one short visit every six months and that they were not entitled to have long visits.
events.event: By a letter of 27 June 2007, the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences informed the second applicant that female life prisoners were entitled to have one long visit every three months, as provided by Article 139 of the Code, given that they served their sentences in medium-security colonies, as provided by Article 18 of the Code. Referring, in particular, to Article 151 of the Code, the Department further stated that male life prisoners were entitled to have one short visit every six months and that they were not entitled to have long visits.
events.event_who: the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences
events.event_what: informed the second applicant about the visiting rights for male and female life prisoners

events.source_text: On 21 January 2010 the Code was amended (“the 2010 amendments”). Article 150, as amended, stated that persons sentenced to life imprisonment were to serve their sentences as follows: male prisoners either in maximum-security sectors of medium-security correctional colonies or in maximum-security correctional colonies; and female prisoners – either in medium-security sectors of minimum-security correctional colonies with general conditions of detention or in medium-security correctional colonies. Article 151, as amended, stated that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every three months.

events.event: The second applicant stated that, because of the lack of the opportunity to have long visits until 2014, he had lost contact with his family. His relatives had died – in particular he referred to his father having died in 2012 – and when the 2014 amendments entitled him to long visits, there had no longer been anyone to visit him.

events.source_text: The third applicant stated that, in the absence of the right to long visits until 2014, his right to found a family had been more declaratory than effective as, in particular, he had not been able to have any physical contact in order to conceive children. The Government submitted that while serving his sentence the third applicant had had twelve short visits (between 25 July 2012 and 26 December 2017) and fourteen long visits (between 5 August 2014 and 6 February 2018) from his wife, mother, father and friends.

events.source_text: Holds (a) that the respondent State is to pay, within three months, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement: (i) EUR 3,000 (three thousand euros) to the first applicant and EUR 1,500 (one thousand five hundred euros) each to the second and third applicants, plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of nonpecuniary damage; (ii) EUR 850 (eight hundred and fifty euros) to the first applicant, plus any tax that may be chargeable to him, in respect of his costs and expenses, to be paid directly to the account of Mr T. Kalmykov;
